questions.question_text: A user is unable to print to a printer on the network. When a technician runs the ping command, the technician receives a response. However, the hostname is not correct when the technician runs the nslookup command. Which of the following BEST describes the issue the technician is seeing?

comments.content: I think that because he used nslookup and it came back with a different host name that theres two devices on the network with the same IP

discussion.content: Obviously a trick question. Duplex is irrelevant. Answer is spooler.
It A "spooler" because the print job didn't even print so checking duplex setting wouldn't help for this question.

A print spooler primarily enables assigning multiple jobs to a printer without affecting the application or the underlying system performance. A printer spooler eliminates the need for an application to be kept engaged, until its printing process is complete.

Im not that good with printers and i really thought it was C, but if you logically think about it spooler is a software that helps with printing and Duplex is just a feature to print both sides. The question states that both sides did not print, so probably something wrong with the spooler. If the question says it printed on one side and not on the other then probably Duplex is the answer.
This is the MAJOR issue in American schools; they are not teaching people to read to comprehend.

comments.content: Why would you assume all users here are americans?
Duplex is the function to print both sides, but since it did not even print at all spooler is the best choice here

No the answer is correct it says "They initiated several print jobs, but none of the jobs printed" so it must be A out of all options available. It just puts prints on both sides to confuse you. Make sure you read the question carefully I have been making loads of stupid mistakes by not reading the question correctly!

questions.question_text: Users in a print room have a new high-end laser printer. They set the printer to print on both sides of the paper by default. They initiated several print jobs, but none of the jobs printed. Which of the following settings should a technician check to resume printing?

comments.content: How do you know 192.168.0.10 is the switch and not another PC

WRONG! the switch is for Layer 2 (Data Link) communication. Switches don't care about IP Addresses, let alone have one (except for multi-layer switches a.k.a L3 switches). First hop must always be the default gateway. in this case, 192.168.0.1. But in this scenario, the computer's first hop went to another IP Address instead (192.168.0.10) so either something is wrong in the computer's IP Stack or the Switch's CAM (content addressable memory) Table (a database in the switch that maps PORT NUMBERS to Mac Addresses) is screwed in which case, a switch reboot usually is needed. So the closest answer is B!

discussion.content: It looks like the tracert was able to connect to the switch (192.168.0.10) but the next hop to the router (default gateway; 192.168.0.1) failed - thus best answer is that switch works and router has a problem.
don't listen to Nick Cave, the answer is correct.

comments.content: a problem with a switch create problem in access LAN resources. Here we have a problem on internet, and what give you access on internet is the router aka default gateway

choices.C: There is a problem with a network switch.
choices.D: The user has an APIPA IP address configured.
choices.B: The wrong subnet mask is configured.
choices.A: There is a problem with a network router.

questions.question_text: A user has returned to headquarters from a remote office and is unable to connect a laptop to the office wireless network. After verifying that the user's laptop is permitted to connect to the headquarters wireless network, the technician should confirm:

discussion.content: How can it be airplane mode if question is about a notebook ? Can notebook has an airplane mode ?
So check Airplane Mode because it's the easiest thing to do first and also maybe after traveling to a remote location he might have turned it ON while traveling like on a plane? ...

airplane mode is a mode on devices (e.g., smartphones and tablets), that disables all wireless communications without having to turn off the device. During a flight, airlines may request electronic devices be turned off or switched to airplane mode to prevent interference with the airplane's communication systems.

While in airplane mode, a cell phone cannot send or receive texts, send or receive calls, or access the Internet. Tablets also cannot access the Internet while in airplane mode. Other devices placed in airplane mode cannot utilize any wireless communication signals.

choices.A: if airplane mode is turned off.
choices.C: if a check for IP conflicts is complete.
choices.B: if the laptop has an APIPA address.
choices.D: if proxy server settings are disabled.

questions.question_text: Which of the following terminates a coaxial cable?

discussion.content:
For people who want a quick guide over what terminates what: 

Coaxial Cables : RG-59 or RG-6 
Ethernet Cables : RJ-45
Phone Line : RJ-11
Serial Cable with RS-232 : DB-9

comments.content: RG-59 does not terminate a coaxial cable. It IS a type of coaxial cable. Let this be an indicator of the integrity of these questions/answers. Proceed at your own risk. Yes, I know this comment will not be approved.

discussion.content:
The question should read which of the following is a type of coaxial cable. RG-59 is actually a type of coax cable not the end terminator piece that screws into the wall. RG-59 does not terminate a coax cable, it is a type of coax cable.
https://sewelldirect.com/blogs/learning-center/what-is-the-difference-between-rg59-and-rg6

comments.content: Although rg-6 and rg-59 actually refer to cables in the context of this Comptia they are used to refer to a cable of this type terminating an an F-Connector. The idea is if you just ask someone for a "coax cable" or an "f-connector cable" you could be handed either or.

discussion.content: F-connector should be on this list...cuz that's my answer

None of the options (A, B, C, D) terminate a coaxial cable.
A. DB9 is a type of serial connector used for RS-232 communications.
B. RJ45 is a type of Ethernet network connector.
C. RG-59 is a type of coaxial cable commonly used for video and broadband signals.
D. RS-232 is a standard for serial data communications.
Coaxial cables are typically terminated with a coaxial connector such as F connector, BNC connector, or RCA connector.

The answer is correct because all the others are not coaxial in nature but as said earlier, the cable itself is RG-59 not the ending. The big takeaway is to know your cables. Even obscur ones can trip you up on exam day! On the job it'll sound professional too using proper item names and avoid confusion between teams. If you ask for a coax cable, they may bring a different gauge than the one you need. Cord names matter :)

comments.content: Believe you got your cert now?

discussion.content: this is the real answers done the1001 twice i was uesing certmaster im going to stick with this answers are REAL happy days
